results.title: Into the Twentieth Century
results.creator_credit: Ian Potts and Educational Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Art of the western world”.
An episode in the comprehensive art history series, Art of the Western World, that focuses on art work from Cubism and abstract art and architecture to Surrealism. Narrated by Michael Wood, this program focuses on the works of such artists as the Fauves, Pablo Picasso, Frank Lloyd Wright, Salvidor Dali and Joan Miro. Through a discussion of the works in their historical, intellectual and social context this program provides both a thorough outline of these periods in art history and underlines their relevance to issues outside the parameters of the works themselves.

results.title: The Aftermath
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “Art of the western world”.
World War II cast a shadow over the development of artists in the post-war years. Virtually every visual arts mode from classical antiquity onwards has had advocates within living memory. Nevertheless, there are substantially novel and radically opposed artistic enterprises which emerged from this time and found form in movements such as Abstract Expressionism, Pop Art and Minimalism.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Northern Renaissance
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The love of minutely observed detail is one of the characteristics that distinguishes the art of the Northern Renaissance from that of Italy. Although the Italians too, studied the surfaces of things, their intent was to work from the inner form outwards, seeking an organising principle or harmony outlying outward appearances. It is in the work of Jan van Eyck and the master Albrecht Durer, that the style of the Northern Renaissance is best showcased.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: Between Utopia and crisis
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The march of Modernism which had begun in the decade before the First World War, continued in the period that followed. The alienation from the centuries-old traditions of Western art became even stronger; the revolutionary attack on bourgeois society and its values broadened from an artisitc minority to political mass movements. The program looks at the challenges of Dadaism and Surrealism, and the architecture of this period.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Passionate eye
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The influence of Napoleon on French art and architecture is examined. The Emperor encouraged the classical Roman style. The age of Romanticism is studied in which the direct expression of natural feeling is extolled above the control of intellect.

results.title: The Legacy of Greece
results.creator_credit: Bayley Silleck, Geoff Dunlop, Channel 4, TVS and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Art of the western world”.
The orgins of humanism and much of Western art can be traced back to Ancient Greece. The development of sculpture, from the archaic, through to classical and the the later more elaborate hellenistic style is discussed by looking at examples of change in the Kouroi and Korai figures. Highlights the perfection reached in architecture, as exemplified by the Parthenon as well as the classic art of pottery decoration in the famous red and black figure vases.

results.title: The Color of man
results.creator_credit: Robert Carl Cohen and University of California, Los Angeles
results.brief_description: Explains the reason for variation in skin color of people of the different nationalities. The film describes how in prehistoric times humans living near the equator could not protect themselves from the direct ultra-violent rays of the sun, and did not survive unless they developed a protective pigment in their skin known as melanin. Similarly those living away from the direct ultra-violet developed a fair skin which permitted the rays to penetrate, for a certain amount of ultra-violet light is essential for life. Narrated by Robert Doubleday.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Carl Cohen and University of California, Los Angeles

results.title: Art of the western world
results.creator_credit: Andrew Snell, Tony Cash, Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description: Traces the history of art from the ancient Greek classical style, to the modern era. Focuses on painting, sculpture and architecture, highlighting the critical works and achievements of the artists of each period. Michael Wood narrates, and renowned art historians give their insight into the history of art.

results.title: New, newer, newest
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “Art of the western world”.
For 200 years, the Western world has been coming to terms with industrialisation and with far reaching social, political and economic change. It has yet to settle with the pluralistic view of cultural history which has resulted from these changes. Beneath a blitz of information about the past, including the quite recent past, Western culture has fractured. This episode examines Conceptualism and the effects on modern day architecture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)

results.title: The Coen brothers
results.brief_description: This low-key documentary on filmmaking brothers Ethan and Joel Coen, was made during the filming of “O Brother where art thou?” The media shy brothers are reputed for playing with established film genres, and a disciplined approach that has enabled them to gain autonomy from studio executives and artistic freedom to create idiosyncratic, original work. Their oeuvre includes “Fargo”, “Raising Arizona”, “The Big Lebowski”, “The Hudsucker proxy”, “Miller’s crossing” and “Barton Fink”. The Coens’ meticulous planning of production allows them to consistently deliver films on budget that often achieve cult status. As a film student Joel was working on others’ low budget films, before undertaking the writing of original scripts with his philosophy graduate brother, Ethan. Their first film, “Blood simple” was an instantaneous alternative classic. The brothers have an unusual style in that they both contribute to filmmaking tasks and share screenwriting recognition, but Joel is credited with directing and Ethan with producing. Features interviews with the Coens, George Clooney, Peter Stormare, Holly Hunter, Jeff Bridges, John Turturro, former school teachers, and a range of close friends who attempt to explain the Coens’ relaxed and symbiotic working relationship. Although they have made the occasional dud, the Coens are consistent in their output and appear to have an untapped well of ideas at their disposal.
